passage_text: Epithet Definition. Epithet is a descriptive literary device that describes a place, a thing or a person in such a way that it helps in making the characteristics of a person, thing or place more prominent than they actually are. Also, it is known as a by-name or descriptive title.

(plural epithets). 1  A term used to characterize a person or thing. 2  A term used as a descriptive substitute for the name or title of a person. 3  An abusive or contemptuous word or phrase. ( 4 biology) A word in the scientific name of a taxon following the name of the genus or species.

Epithet Examples. Epithet. Epithet is the literary term for the application of a word or phrase to someone that describes that person's attributes or qualities. Kenning examples may also be considered as epithet examples. Kenning is a type of an epithet, which is a two-word phrase that describes an object by employing metaphors. The Fixed Epithet. Fixed epithets are found in epic poetry that involves the repetitive use of a phrase or word for the same object.

An epithet (from Greek: ἐπίθετον epitheton, neut. of ἐπίθετος epithetos, attributed, added) is a byname, or a descriptive term (word or phrase), accompanying or occurring in place of a name and having entered common usage. It can be described as a glorified nickname.
